Vapor-phase catalytic dehydration of 1,4-butanediol (1,4-BDO) was investigated over Y2O3-ZrO2 catalysts. In the dehydration, 1,3-butadiene (BD) together with 3-buten-1-ol (3B1OL), tetrahydrofuran, and propylene was produced depending on the reaction conditions. In the dehydration over Y2O3-ZrO2 catalysts with different Y contents at 325°C, Y2Zr2O7 with an equimolar ratio of Y/Zr showed high selectivity to 3B1OL, an intermediate to BD. In the dehydration at 360°C, a BD yield higher than 90% was achieved over the Y2Zr2O7 calcined at 700°C throughout 10 h. In the dehydration of 3B1OL over Y2Zr2O7, however, the catalytic activity affected by the calcination temperature is roughly proportional to the specific surface area of the sample. The highest activity of Y2Zr2O7 calcined at 700 °C for the BD formation from 1,4-BDO is explained by the trade-off relation in the activities for the first-step dehydration of 1,4-BDO to 3B1OL and for the second-step dehydration of 3B1OL to BD. The higher reactivity of 3B1OL than saturated alcohols such as 1-butanol and 2-butanol suggests that the C=C double bond of 3B1OL induces an attractive interaction to anchor the catalyst surface and promotes the dehydration. A probable mechanism for the one-step dehydration of 1,4-BDO to BD was discussed. Graphic abstrast Image, graphical abstract Keywords Production of 1,3-butadiene Dehydration of 1,4-butanediol Y2Zr2O7 Cubic fluorite 1 Introduction 1,3-Butadiene (BD) is a beneficial compound used as a raw material for synthetic rubbers and resins. Currently, 98% of BD is obtained as a by-product of naphtha cracking in ethylene plants, and thus the supply of ethylene influences the supply and price of BD. In recent years, with the revolution of shale gas in the United States, ethylene can be readily produced by ethane cracking. As a result, the supply for ethylene obtained from naphtha is decreasing, and the shortage of BD supply raised the market price of BD [1-4]. In addition, aggravation of the global environment due to carbon dioxide produced from fossil resources is also a significant problem. In order to solve these problems, there is a growing demand for a new synthetic process to produce BD from biomass-derived carbon-neutral raw materials. Biomass-derived 1,4-butanediol (1,4-BDO) can be obtained through microbial fermentation and catalytic conversion processes. 1,4-BDO can be obtained from glucose and xylose by microbial fermentation using Escherichia coli [4-6]: 3.83 g L−1 of 1,4-BDO can be produced from xylose with a yield of 0.37g gxylose −1, which corresponds to the 1,4-BDO selectivity of 63 mol% [6]. In addition, 1,4-BDO can be produced from succinic acid and furfural obtained from glucose in good yields of 80% or higher through catalytic conversion processes [7,8]. It has already been reported that BD can be produced from diols [4,9-14]. In the dehydration of 1,4-BDO, solid acid catalysts such as γ-Al2O3 and SiO2-Al2O3 show an efficient cyclization ability to form tetrahydrofuran (THF) at a temperature of 275 °C [4,15]. In the one-step dehydration of 1,4-BDO to BD, a BD yield of 96.6% is achieved over Yb2O3 at 360°C [12]. An industrial process to produce BD from 1,4-BDO has been investigated [16]. It is reported the process consists of two steps, which include esterification of 1,4-BDO followed by pyrolysis of 1,4-BDO diester to produce BD. In the process, 0.57 tons of BD, which is a stoichiometric yield of 95.9%, is produced from a ton of 1,4-BDO. However, the second step of pyrolysis of 1,4-BDO diester to produce BD requires a temperature of 500°C or higher. Scheme 1 shows the production route of BD in the dehydration of 1,4-BDO. 1,4-BDO produces mainly 3-buten-1-ol (3B1OL), followed by isomerization to form unsaturated alcohols (UOLs) such as 2-buten-1-ol (2B1OL) and 3-buten-2-ol (3B2OL). The major by-products are THF and propylene through the decomposition of 3B1OL. Several catalysts such as rare earth oxides (REO) [15,17-20], ZrO2 [20-23], and rare earth zirconates (REZrO) [24,25] have been reported as an efficient catalyst for the formation of 3B1OL from 1,4-BDO. As for the production of UOLs, Y2Zr2O7 calcined at 900 °C shows high activity, such as a 3B1OL selectivity of 87.7% at a 1,4-BDO conversion of 77.6% at 325 °C [25]. Recently, it is reported that the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst is also efficient for the formation of BD from 1,3-BDO, achieving a high BD yield of 95% at 375°C [14]. It is considered that the dehydration of 1,4-BDO and 1,3-BDO to UOLs proceeds selectively on the (111) plane of the cubic fluorite structure of Yb2Zr2O7 [24], Y2Zr2O7 [25], and CeO2 [26]. We have reported an important finding that a hydrothermal (HT) aging of the precursor hydroxide in an ammonia solution provides excellent Yb2Zr2O7 catalysts with high crystallinity of oxygen-defected fluorite structure as well as relatively high specific surface areas, which show high activity for the dehydration of 1,3-BDO [24]. In this study, we investigated the selective production BD from 1,4-BDO in a one-step process (Scheme 1) using REZrO catalysts prepared by an HT aging method. To clarify the feature of efficient catalyst for the BD formation, we tested several catalysts for the catalytic activity of UOLs (Scheme 1b). As for the second-step dehydration, it has been suggested that the double bond of UOLs could act as an anchor for the reaction to proceed [12], so that we also conducted catalytic activity tests of C4 saturated alcohols such as 1-butanol and 2-butanol to discuss the reaction mechanism. 2 Experimental 2.1 Samples An yttrium zirconate, Y2Zr2O7, was prepared through HT aging using a precipitate prepared from an aqueous solution of Y(NO3)3·H2O and ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O with an equimolar amount of Y and Zr. The finally obtained catalyst sample was calcined at a temperature between 600 and 1000°C for 3 h. Hereafter, the calcined yttrium zirconate is named Y2Zr2O7-T, where T is the calcination temperature (°C). Y2O3-ZrO2 (YZrO) samples with different Y contents were prepared in the same way as that of Y2Zr2O7 described above, which is expressed as xYZrO where x is Y content (mol%). Preparation of other REZrO samples is described elsewhere [25]. Reference acidic catalysts such as Al2O3 (JRC-ALO-7; specific surface area, SA =180 m2 g−1) and SiO2-Al2O3 (JRC-SAL-3; SA=416 m2 g−1) were supplied by Catalyst Society of Japan. 2.2 Catalytic reaction The vaper-phase catalytic reaction was performed in a fixed-bed down-flow glass tube reactor with an inner diameter of 17 mm under an atmospheric pressure of N2 at a temperature between 300 and 425°C. After the catalyst, typically 0.5 g, had been heated in N2 flow at a flow rate of 30 cm3 min−1 at the prescribed reaction temperature for 1 h, a reactant BDO was fed into the reactor at a liquid feed rate of 1.60 g h−1. The reaction effluent was collected at either 0 or -78°C every hour: the reaction effluent was collected at 0°C when the conversion was 80% or higher, and the reaction temperature was 350°C or higher. The liquid products collected in a trap were identified by gas chromatography (GC) using a mass spectrometer (GCMS-QP5050 A, Shimadzu) with a capillary column (DB-WAX, a length of 30 m, JW Scientific). The products were quantified by GC (FIDGC-8 A, Shimadzu) with a direct injection unit and a capillary column (Inert Cap WAX-HT, inner diameter of 0.53 mm, a length of 30 m, GL-Science). In the quantitative GC analysis, 1-hexanol was used as an internal standard. Gaseous products such as BD, propylene, and CO2 were collected with a 0.5 cm3 gastight syringe and analyzed in another GC-8A equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a packed column (VZ-7, a length of 6 m, GL-Science) using N2 carrier gas as an internal standard. The catalytic activity was evaluated by averaging the conversion and selectivity data for four hours from time on stream of 1 to 5 hours, excluding the first period of 1 h. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The X-ray diffraction (XRD) of YZrO catalysts was performed with New D8 ADVANCE (Bruker) using Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.154 nm) to identify the crystalline phase of the catalyst. The N2 adsorption measurement was carried out in a self-constructed volumetric gas adsorption apparatus at −196°C. Three-point data for the N2 adsorption at P/P 0 range between 0.05 and 0.35 was analyzed by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation to calculate the specific surface area (SA) of the catalyst. To construct the crystal structure of Y2Zr2O7 and Y2O3, crystal structure modeling was performed using VESTA 3 software [27] with the National Institute for Materials Science (NIMS) AtomWork Database [28] including crystallographic data of Y2Zr2O7 [29] and Y2O3 [30]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic dehydration of 1,4-BDO over REZrO catalysts In our previous work, we have recently reported that the selective dehydration of 1,4-BDO to 3B1OL proceeded over REZrO catalysts with heavy rare earth at a reaction temperature of 325°C [25]. The REZrO samples calcined at 900 °C have been characterized by using XRD and X-ray fluorescence analysis. The crystal phase of Y2Zr2O7 was confirmed by Rietveld analysis. Furthermore, the physical properties of Y2Zr2O7-900 were evaluated by acid-base evaluation, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm, and high-resolution field emission scanning electron microscope images. Eight REZrO samples listed in Table 1 have a single crystal phase of cubic fluorite such as Y2Zr2O7 for Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, and Lu. However, Eu2Zr2O7 and Gd2Zr2O7 are a mixture of cubic fluorite and cubic bixbyite Eu2O3 or Eu2O3. In the beginning of this study, the catalytic activity of REZrO was tested at a high reaction temperature of 375°C to investigate the one-step formation of BD from 1,4-BDO. Table 1 summarizes the catalytic activity of ten REZrO samples in the dehydration of 1,4-BDO at a low space time W/F = 0.31 h, where W and F are catalyst weight and reactant feed rate, respectively. Y2Zr2O7-900 and Dy2Zr2O7-900 showed high BD yields of more than 58%, and the major by-products were THF, 3B1OL, 2B1OL, and propylene. The activity tests of Y2Zr2O7 and Dy2Zr2O7, which showed high BD selectivity, were carried out at 360°C and W/F = 2.5 h for 10 h, where the calcination temperature is 800°C (Fig. S1). Y2Zr2O7-900 catalyst showed more stable activity than Dy2Zr2O7-900, so that the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst was investigated in detail in the following sections. 3.2 Dehydration of 1,4-BDO over YZrO catalysts with different Y contents It is important to determine an active phase of YZrO catalysts. At first, the optimum ratio of Y/Zr in YZrO catalysts was examined by varying the Y content from 0 to 100 mol%. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts with different Y contents. It was confirmed that the crystal phase of YZrO samples calcined at 900 °C varied with Y content. At Y content of 0 mol%, i.e. ZrO2, the crystal phase was monoclinic. At Y contents of 2-4 mol% (XRD patterns not shown), the crystal phase has been reported to be a mixture of monoclinic and tetragonal zirconia phases [20]. At Y contents of 6-25 mol%, the crystal phase was a tetragonal, i.e. Y-stabilized zirconia. At Y contents of 31-43 mol%, the crystal phase was a cubic fluorite. At a Y content of 50 mol%, it has been reported that 50YZrO sample is Y2Zr2O7 with a defective fluorite-type structure (PDF 01-074-9311, Fd-3 m, No. 227) [25]. At Y contents of 57-75 mol%, the catalyst sample was a mixture of cubic fluorite Y2Zr2O7 with 2θ = 29.9 degree (Fig. 1b) and cubic bixbyite Y2O3 with 2θ = 29.2 degree (PDF 01-071-0049, Ia-3, No. 206). At a Y content of 100 mol%, the crystal phase was a cubic bixbyite Y2O3 (100YZrO). Fig. 2 shows changes in the conversion of 1,4-BDO and the selectivity to 3B1OL with Y content. In comparison, Fig. S2 shows the catalytic activity of the same samples in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO. The reactant BDOs have similar reactivity for the dehydration over the YZrO catalysts [25]: 1,3-BDO is slightly more reactive than 1,4-BDO. In both reactions, catalysts with a single cubic fluorite phase at Y contents of 31-50 mol% including Y2Zr2O7 showed a higher selectivity to UOLs than the other phases such as tetragonal Y-stabilized zirconia and mixed phases. It is considered that the dehydration of 1,4-BDO to produce 3B1OL proceeds at specific crystal planes [20], and the high 3B1OL selectivity over cubic fluorite catalysts could be due to single active sites provided on the fluorite surface. At Y contents of 50 mol% or higher, a decrease in the 1,4-BDO conversion was observed with a decrease in the SA. The decrease in the 1,4-BDO conversion in 100YZrO, i.e. Y2O3, could be attributed to the difference between the crystal phases in cubic fluorite Y2Zr2O7 with oxygen defects and cubic bixbyite Y2O3 [12,25]. This difference is discussed as follows. From the Rietveld analysis [25], it is confirmed that 50YZrO is a Y2Zr2O7 with an oxygen-defected fluorite structure. The cubic fluorite, CeO2, has a predominantly (111) plane, and the oxygen defects on the (111) plane serve as adsorption sites for the dehydration of BDOs [26]. The heavy rare earth oxides such as Yb2O3 have a cubic bixbyite structure, and the (222) plane is the most stable [31,32]. In a similar way to the cubic CeO2, the oxygen defects on the surface of Y2Zr2O7 and Y2O3 are considered to act as adsorption sites for 1,4-BDO. To discuss the difference in activity depending on the structure, Fig. 3 , which was constructed by VESTA modeling [27] with crystallographic data [28-30], shows the top view of the upper three layers of (111) plane of the cubic oxygen-defected fluorite Y2Zr2O7 (Fig. 3a-c) and those of (222) plane of the cubic bixbyite Y2O3 (Fig. 3d,e). The Y2Zr2O7 (111) surface has oxygen in 87.5% of the oxygen-occupied sites of the cubic crystal, i.e., 12.5% oxygen vacancies of the oxygen-occupied sites [25]. This means that 1/8 of the surface oxygen occupied sites of Y2Zr2O7 are vacancies (12 O defects seen in Fig. 3a). In contrast, vacancies occupy 1/4 of the surface oxygen sites in the stable (222) plane of cubic bixbyite Y2O3 (24 O defects seen in Fig. 3d). Fig. 4 shows the formation rate of 3B1OL per unit surface area at different Y contents. The formation rate varied with Y content, and it seems dependent on the crystal structure: the formation rates over cubic catalysts are higher than those over tetragonal catalysts. In the same cubic structure, the formation rate over fluorite Y2Zr2O7 is three times as high as that over bixbyite Y2O3, although the ratio of surface oxygen defects in the cubic bixbyite Y2O3 is twice as high as that of fluorite Y2Zr2O7 (Fig. 3d). However, the difference between the catalysts is the position of the oxygen defects. In the cubic oxygen-defected fluorite Y2Zr2O7, 1/8 of the surface oxygen are randomly defected with an isolated position, as shown in Fig. 3a where 12 O defects are observed. It is reasonable that each defect of the oxygen vacancies acts as an adsorption site. On the other hand, clusters of vacancies of four oxygen-occupied sites like a three-rayed star are regularly located on the surface of cubic bixbyite Y2O3 [31,32], as shown in Fig. 3d where 24 O defects constructed from 6 clusters with four O defects are present. If a cluster with four O defects acts as an adsorption site, the ratio of adsorption sites on the surface corresponds 1/16. In the cubic bixbyite Y2O3, the fraction of surface adsorption sites is a half of the cubic oxygen-defected fluorite Y2Zr2O7. The consideration on the defect sites, therefore, can explain the superiority of the cubic fluorite Y2Zr2O7 to the cubic bixbyite Y2O3 in the 3B1OL formation rate shown in Fig. 4. We have further taken into consideration on the active sites as follows. In a cubic fluorite Y2Zr2O7, an average value of the ionic radius of Y and Zr, which is regarded as a representative distance, is calculated to be 0.087 nm from the ionic radii of Y (0.0900 nm) and Zr (0.0840 nm) [33]. The average value of Y-Zr in Y2Zr2O7 is close to that of the ionic radius of Yb (0.0868 nm [33]) in Yb2O3 that showed high activity produce BD from 1,4-BDO [12], suggesting that the distance between cations on the surface could be significantly related to the catalytic activity. Actually, the formation rate of 3B1OL over Yb2O3 is 1.3 times as high as that of Y2O3 in the dehydration of 1,4-BDO at 375 °C [18]. 3.3 Catalytic dehydration of 1,4-BDO over Y2Zr2O7 catalyst under different conditions Fig. 5 shows the 1,4-BDO conversion and the selectivity to each product at different reaction temperatures in the dehydration over Y2Zr2O7-900. The fed 1,4-BDO was completely consumed at 350 °C or higher. As the reaction temperature increased, the selectivity to BD increased, and that for 3B1OL decreased. This means that the generated 3B1OL is dehydrated to BD at high temperatures. At 375°C, however, propylene was produced, and the selectivity to propylene increased with the temperature. This is due to the decomposition of 3B1OL by the retro-Prince reaction, which is favorable at high temperatures [12,14]. The total selectivity to UOLs and BD was higher than 85.3% at 400 °C or lower, while it was lowered to 79.4% at 425 °C. Also, at 425°C, the BD selectivity decreased steeply with time on stream, and the THF selectivity increased (Fig. S3). Since the catalytic activity was relatively stable at temperatures lower than 425 °C, the change in the selectivity would be caused by deactivation of catalyst probably because of coke deposition: it is possible that the active site for the dehydration of 3B1OL to BD was poisoned by coke deposition at high reaction temperatures. Since propylene and THF are formed as by-products at high reaction temperatures, the effect of space time was investigated at a low temperature of 360°C, at which propylene formation is small. Fig. 6 shows the change in the conversion and the selectivity at 360°C with space time. As the space time increased, the UOLs and THF selectivity decreased, and thus the BD selectivity increased. It is previously reported the dehydration of THF to BD [34,35]: THF conversion of 89.1% with BD selectivity of 84.7% is attained over an acid catalyst at 400 °C [34]. However, in this case, the THF selectivity, as well as the BD selectivity, decreased with time on stream, and the UOLs selectivity increased (Fig. S4). Therefore, this suggests that the dehydration from UOLs to BD proceeded on the Y2Zr2O7-900 catalyst, not from THF. Under the conditions of a high space time of W/F =2.5 h, the UOLs selectivity became nearly 0, i.e. the dehydration in the second step proceeded completely. 3.4 Catalytic dehydration of 1,4-BDO over Y2Zr2O7 calcined at different temperatures Fig. 7 shows the effect of calcination temperature of Y2Zr2O7 on the changes in the yield of BD and 3B1OL in the dehydration of 1,4-BDO, and the numerical data are displayed in Table S1. In the 10-h reaction, Y2Zr2O7-700 maintained the highest BD yield where the 3B1OL selectivity was 0.0%, indicating that the dehydration of 3B1OL to BD was complete. On the other hand, the BD yield decreased in the Y2Zr2O7 samples calcined at 600, 900, and 1000°C with time on stream. The yields of BD and 3B1OL were not steady during the 10-h reaction. The SA of used Y2Zr2O7-700 was reduced from the fresh one of 78.6 to 71.8 m2 g−1. The SA decreased with increasing the calcination temperature (Fig. 8 and Table S1), suggesting that the decrease in the BD yield in the range of calcination temperatures between 700 and 1000 °C is correlated with the decrease in the SA of the samples. The slight decrease in the BD yield with time on stream even at a high space time would be caused by the deactivation of active sites for the dehydration of 3B1OL. The coke deposition on the catalysts was estimated by the decrease in weight in thermogravimetric analysis, as shown in Fig. S7: the coke content was proportional to the SA of the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst (Table S1). In our previous study, we have confirmed that raising the calcination temperature improves the crystallinity and the selectivity to 3B1OL [25]. Over the Y2Zr2O7-600 with low crystallinity, however, both the conversion of 1,4-BDO and the selectivity to 3B1OL were low irrespective of the high SA. A similar trend was observed in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD [14]. Therefore, it is reasonable that the Y2Zr2O7-700 is located at the maximum in the tradeoff curve between the activity in the dehydration of 1,4-BDO to 3B1OL and the dehydration of 3B1OL to BD. We will discuss why the dehydration from 3B1OL to BD becomes more difficult to proceed over the samples calcined at high temperatures in the following section. 3.5 The dehydration of UOLs to BD over Y2Zr2O7 In the formation of BD from 1,4-BDO, 3B1OL is a key intermediate [12]. To investigate the second-step dehydration (Scheme 1b), the reactivity test of 3B1OL over Y2Zr2O7 catalysts was carried out. Fig. 8 shows the effect of the calcination temperature of Y2Zr2O7 on the dehydration of 3B1OL at 360 °C. Both the 3B1OL conversion and the BD selectivity were the highest in the Y2Zr2O7-600, and they were decreased with increasing the calcination temperature. The decrease in the 3B1OL conversion is comparable to the decrease in SA. In the dehydration of 2B1OL over Y2Zr2O7 [14], we have also reported similar trends to those observed in Fig. 8: the conversion of 2B1OL decreased with increasing calcination temperature together with the decrease in SA of the catalyst, except the Y2Zr2O7-500. Thus, the decrease in the UOLs conversion with calcination temperature is caused by the decrease in SA. This suggests that the active catalysts for the dehydration of UOLs to BD do not need high crystallinity of fluorite Y2Zr2O7. Namely, the dehydration of UOLs to BD would be catalyzed by the not-so-well-defined structure of active sites as well as by the active sites for the dehydration of BDOs, which need high crystallinity of fluorite Y2Zr2O7. Fig. 9 shows the changes in the conversion of 3B1OL over Y2Zr2O7 with time on stream. Deactivation during the initial period for 5 h was observed in all the Y2Zr2O7 samples irrespective of calcination temperature. Therefore, in the dehydration of 1,4-BDO to BD (Fig. 7), the slight decrease in the BD yield even at a high space time would be caused by the deactivation of active sites for the dehydration of 3B1OL. Table 2 and Fig. S5 show the results of the dehydration of UOLs such as 3B1OL, 2B1OL, and 3B2OL over Y2Zr2O7-900 at 360 °C. Among the UOLs, deactivation behaviors of Y2Zr2O7-900 are different (Fig. S5): the conversion of 3B1OL and 3B2OL decreased with time on stream, while that of 2B1OL remained constant. In the reaction of 3B1OL (Fig. S5a), a certain amount of propylene was produced. The propylene yield remained constant throughout the initial 5 h, suggesting that the reaction was independent and unrelated to the isomerization of 3B1OL to 2B1OL and the dehydration of 3B1OL to BD. In the dehydration of 2B1OL and 3B2OL (Fig. S5b, c), non-formation of propylene indicates that propylene forms in the retro-Prince reaction of 3B1OL. In the dehydration of 2B1OL, the BD yield increased with time on stream. This is probably because 2B1OL is an intermediate in the formation of BD, and the dehydration of 2B1OL to BD proceeded because the isomerization of 2B1OL to 3B2OL was suppressed with time on stream. In addition, over typical acidic catalysts such as alumina and silica-alumina, both the dehydration of 2B1OL to BD and the isomerization of 2B1OL to 3B2OL proceeded (Table S2). However, the catalysts behaved differently: the dehydration to BD was dominant over silica-alumina, and the isomerization to 3B2OL was preferable over alumina. This difference could be possibly explained by the acid property: in general, silica-alumina has dominantly Brønsted acid and alumina has majorly Lewis acid. It has been recently found that the isomerization between 2B1OL and 3B2OL is catalyzed by Lewis acid of V2O5-SiO2 [36]. The dehydration of C4 linear saturated alcohols such as 1-butanol and 2-butanol is shown in Table 2, and the time-course of the conversion of 1- and 2-butanol comparing with those of UOLs is displayed in Fig. S6. The dehydration of 2B1OL and 1-butanol had no deactivation with time on stream, whereas deactivation with time on stream was observed in the dehydration of 3B1OL, 3B2OL, and 2-butanol. The deactivation may be due to the polymerization of alkenes such as propylene and butene. The reactivity of UOLs over Y2Zr2O7-900 catalyst is higher than that of butanols regardless of the position of the OH group. These results support our previous prediction [12] that the dehydration of 3B1OL proceeds by anchoring by the double bond of UOLs to the surface (Scheme 2 a). However, the reactivity of the monoalcohols over a typical acidic catalyst such as alumina (Table S2) is different from that over Y2Zr2O7-900 (Table 2). The reactivity of the monoalcohols over alumina was in the order of 2B1OL > 2-butanol > 1-butanol > 3B1OL, while silica-alumina had the order of 2B1OL > 2-butanol > 3B1OL > 1-butanol. In addition, the reactivity order of 2B1OL > 1-butanol > 3B1OL over H-ZSM-5 is also reported [35]. In these acid catalysts, 3B1OL is not always more reactive than 1-butanol. Furthermore, 3B1OL is readily decomposed via retro-Prince reaction over acidic catalysts such as alumina and silica-alumina [37], indicating that a butenyl cation would be hardly formed over the solid acids. On the other hand, over Y2Zr2O7 catalysts, 3B1OL was dehydrated to BD together with the isomer of 2B1OL and a small amount of propylene, as shown in Fig. S5a. Thus, the dehydration of 3B1OL would be explained by E2 mechanism (Scheme 2a) rather than E1 mechanism via carbocation over Y2Zr2O7 catalysts. Because the much higher reactivity of 3B1OL than 1-butanol (Table 2) is limited by the surface of Y2Zr2O7-900, an attractive interaction between 3B1OL and Y2Zr2O7 could accelerate the dehydration. Thus, we propose that the double bond of UOLs acts as an anchor to the surface in the dehydration of 3B1OL (Scheme 2a) in contrast to 1-butanol that has no interaction of alkyl group with the surface (Scheme 2b). In the dehydration of 2-butanol, 2-butene was expected to be the main product over acidic catalysts according to the Zaitsev rule (Table S2), whereas 1-butene was the most abundant product over Y2Zr2O7-900 (Table 2). In the pioneering reports, REO catalysts such as Yb2O3 and Y2O3 have Hoffmann elimination ability in the dehydration of 2-alcohol [38-40]. REO catalysts produced α-olefins such as 1-butene and 4-methyl-1-pentene with high selectivity in the dehydration of 2-butanol and 4-methyl-2-pentanol, respectively [38,39]. It is also known that ZrO2 has Hoffmann elimination ability with acid-base bifunctional catalysis in the dehydration of 2-butanol [41]. It is interesting that ThO2 with a fluorite structure also has a high Hoffmann elimination ability [38]. Therefore, it can be concluded that the Y2Zr2O7 catalysts also promote the Hoffmann elimination of 2-alcohol in a similar manner to Y2O3 [38] and ZrO2 [41]. We have discussed that REO catalyst accelerates the Hoffmann elimination in the dehydration of 2-alcohols, but there is no Hoffmann-ruled product distribution in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO over Yb2O3 [42], other REOs [43], and Y2Zr2O7 [25]. Because two OH groups of 1,3-BDO obviously contribute to the adsorption of 1,3-BDO [25,42,43], it is reasonable that the dehydration of 1,3-BDO does not obey the elimination rules of Hoffmann and Zaitsev. 3.6 Mechanistic consideration of the formation of BD from 1,4-BDO We have discussed the reactivity of monoalcohols in the previous section. It is plausible that 3B1OL is much less reactive than 1,4-BDO over Y2Zr2O7 because the 3B1OL selectivity is quite high even at high conversions. After the reactant 1,4-BDO had been consumed at the complete conversion, 3B1OL could be reacted because the reactivity order is 1,4-BDO > 3B1OL > 1-butanol, as mentioned above. Scheme 3 proposes a speculative reaction mechanism for the formation of BD in the dehydration of 1,4-BDO over a defect site of Y2Zr2O7, which is illustrated in Fig. 3c. The selective formation of 3B1OL in the dehydration of 1,4-BDO over the defect site is explained by the adsorption as the form of tridentate coordination of 1,4-BDO to Y3+ and Zr4+ cations and an O2− anion (Scheme 3a) [25]. A sequential dehydration proceeds: a hydrogen of 1,4-BDO at position 2 is firstly abstracted by a basic O2− anion and then an OH group at position 1 is subsequently or simultaneously abstracted by an acidic Y3+ cation. The other OH group at position 4 plays a significant role of anchoring 1,4-BDO to the surface. A similar mechanism of the 1,4-BDO dehydration over Gd2O3 catalyst is supported by theoretical calculation [44]. In the second step, the produced 3B1OL could be promptly adsorbed on the defect site at the complete conversion of 1,4-BDO (Scheme 3b). Because 1,4-BDO is more reactive than 3B1OL, 3B1OL can be dehydrated after 1,4-BDO has been consumed. Both the first-step dehydration of 1,4-BDO to produce 3B1OL and the second-step dehydration of 3B1OL to BD could proceed via the base-acid concerted mechanism. The high BD yield higher than 90% in the dehydration of 1,4-BDO can be supported by the mechanism of Scheme 3: the two-step dehydration of 1,4-BDO may separately proceed, but it could simultaneously proceed without desorbing a 3B1OL intermediate in the BD formation at high temperatures as 360 °C. 4 Conclusions Vapor-phase catalytic dehydration of 1,4-BDO was investigated over REZrO catalysts prepared by the HT aging method. Among ten REZrO catalysts, Y2Zr2O7 and Dy2Zr2O7 catalysts showed particularly high catalytic activity, and the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst was more stable than the Dy2Zr2O7. Especially, Y2Zr2O7-700 shows the complete conversion of 1,4-BDO with a high BD selectivity of 92.9% at 360°C during the time on stream of 10 h. In the dehydration of 1,4-BDO over YZrO catalysts with different Y contents at 325°C, Y2Zr2O7 with a Y/Zr ratio of 1, which has a cubic oxygen-defected fluorite structure, showed the highest BD formation rate with high selectivity for 3B1OL. Although the density of surface oxygen vacancies in the cubic bixbyite Y2O3 is higher than that in the cubic oxygen-defected fluorite Y2Zr2O7, the formation rate of 3B1OL over the Y2Zr2O7 was higher than Y2O3. This is explained by the difference in the aggregate state of the oxygen vacancies. In the dehydration of 1,4-BDO over Y2Zr2O7 calcined at different temperatures, the highest BD yield was observed in Y2Zr2O7-700 at 360 °C. In the first-step dehydration of 1,4-BDO to 3B1OL over Y2Zr2O7 at 325 °C, Y2Zr2O7-900 showed the highest yield of 3B1OL [25]. On the contrary, in the second-step dehydration of 3B1OL to BD over Y2Zr2O7 at 360 °C, the highest BD yield was observed in Y2Zr2O7-600, and the BD yield decreased with increasing calcination temperature. Therefore, the highest activity of Y2Zr2O7-700 in the one-step dehydration of 1,4-BDO to produce BD can be explained by the trade-off relation in the activities for the first-step dehydration of 1,4-BDO to 3B1OL and for the second-step dehydration of 3B1OL to BD. In addition to 3B1OL, the dehydration reactivity of UOLs such as 2B1OL and 3B2OL that are isomers of 3B1OL as well as that of saturated alcohols such as 1-butanol and 2-butanol was examined. Regardless of the position of the OH group, all UOLs had higher reactivity than the saturated alcohols. The C=C double bond of the UOLs could have an attractive interaction such as anchoring to the catalyst surface, thereby promoting the dehydration to BD. This suggests that the two-step dehydration of 1,4-BDO simultaneously proceeds without desorbing a 3B1OL intermediate in the BD formation in the dehydration of 1,4-BDO at high temperatures as 360 °C. coredata.dc:description: Vapor-phase catalytic dehydration of 1,4-butanediol (1,4-BDO) was investigated over Y2O3-ZrO2 catalysts. In the dehydration, 1,3-butadiene (BD) together with 3-buten-1-ol (3B1OL), tetrahydrofuran, and propylene was produced depending on the reaction conditions. In the dehydration over Y2O3-ZrO2 catalysts with different Y contents at 325°C, Y2Zr2O7 with an equimolar ratio of Y/Zr showed high selectivity to 3B1OL, an intermediate to BD. In the dehydration at 360°C, a BD yield higher than 90% was achieved over the Y2Zr2O7 calcined at 700°C throughout 10 h. In the dehydration of 3B1OL over Y2Zr2O7, however, the catalytic activity affected by the calcination temperature is roughly proportional to the specific surface area of the sample. The highest activity of Y2Zr2O7 calcined at 700 °C for the BD formation from 1,4-BDO is explained by the trade-off relation in the activities for the first-step dehydration of 1,4-BDO to 3B1OL and for the second-step dehydration of 3B1OL to BD. The higher reactivity of 3B1OL than saturated alcohols such as 1-butanol and 2-butanol suggests that the C=C double bond of 3B1OL induces an attractive interaction to anchor the catalyst surface and promotes the dehydration. A probable mechanism for the one-step dehydration of 1,4-BDO to BD was discussed.
